Hi Varsha,

If we're changing the public API of the library then I'd very much prefer we add an entry to the changelog. Working through the checklist at https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/docs/checklists/changes.md will help make sure everything necessary is covered off.

Beyond that, I've commented on some concerns inline.
Done

Should we be using "FRU" here? Why not PDR? If it is a FRU type in the formal (DSP0257?) sense, is there a reason "fru" is not in the type names?

This query probably extends beyond the scope of the patch, but I wonder if there's a missed opportunity for more tightly constraining the types.

I have added a bit more detail to @brief here and I feel FRU should be used since this API is meant for FRU records. I understand making it more meaningful in a broader sense, I am looking into what term I can use here
removed FRU from the description but it is still there in the API name
Done
In the same vein, do we expect to be allocating in the remove path?
I don't think this should be a problem for _removing_ a record?
removed this
removed this
Done
Done

I think it would be more ergonomic with the signature

```
static pldm_pdr_record *pldm_pdr_get_prev_record(const pldm_pdr *repo,
    const pldm_pdr_record *record);
```

That way we just return the previous record (or `NULL`) directly.
Done
Can we add `assert(repo->size >= record->size)` _above_ (in addition to) this check?
Done

We really must only do this if we know we've removed the record. For instance, what if we try to remove the same record twice? This obviously isn't a sensible thing to do when so directly stated, but that doesn't mean that there won't be some other bug in the calling applications that causes the condition.

So we need to know the record actually exists in the repo first. The hints we have that it is not are that `pldm_pdr_get_prev_record()` returns `NULL`, and that `record` is neither the first nor last in the repo.

Without ensuring that it's actually part of the repo we will corrupt the repo size and cause an error that has a large separation in time from the failure.
included checks for above
Done
In addition, we need to test that the other two records are still present.
Done
Please also test other conditions like trying to remove the same record twice, followed by removing all records successfully.
i have included other cases but removing the same record twice will just return rc = 0 because when match is not found for fru_rsi no remove will be done
That's because you've fixed the implementation. But the implementation might change in the future and we want to protect against reintroducing that problem.
I have addressed this. I was wrong I check the record handle to verify this test
Done
Tested section?
this has been unit tested
Hi Varsha. I have a number of comments, many of them are similar to the previous patch.
apologies for the delay will update this commit today
nit: have a better naming convention of the variables
Acknowledged
Done
Trailing whitespace.
Done
Just `assert()` it and punt the check here out to the caller?
Done
Please put all variable declarations before the implementation.
Done

Please no pointer arithmetic when initialising the msgbuf.

If you want to skip regions, use `plmd_msgbuf_span_required()` for now.
Done
Please just pass the size of the `record->data` buffer.
Done
This must be `pldm_msgbuf_extract()` or else the endianness is broken.
Done
`return record_fru_rsi && *record_fru_rsi == rsi;`
Done
`assert()`, but also what about `prev`?

done for record and repo 

if record = repo->first then there is possibility for prev to be NULL in this case
Done
Please declare variables before any implementation.
Done
Please no pointer arithmetic when initialising the msgbuf. Use `pldm_msgbuf_span_required()` if you need to skip a region for now.
Done
This must be `pldm_msgbuf_extract()`.
Done
Each test should be in its own `#ifdef`, please don't combine them.
Done
Hi Varsha, I have a few suggestions inline.

@arj, I understand that you may be unhappy with the declaration done here. But here is the problem I faced- 

I need to declare a pointer to be used in pldm_msgbuf_span_required because I need to skip some data in msgbuf and extract one specific data. When I put this inside a while loop I end up reusing the same pointer. This pointer is not initialized correctly in the next iteration that results in msgbuf pointing to the wrong address. I am not sure how to deference or reinitialize this pointer *skip_hdr_data and reuse the same variable inside while loop
If we allow `pldm_msgbuf_span_required()` to accept `NULL` for the cursor then this problem goes away. See my request on your previous patch 😊
Done
Need to test the return value here before using `hdr_type`.
Done
Please make this cleanup a common path toward the end of the function, and use a label and goto to jump to it.
Done
Please invert the condition and jump to an appropriate cleanup label so we can un-nest the code here.
Done
Hi Varsha, a couple of thoughts inline.
Done
I feel like we need to give this some more thought to avoid the weird break here.
I have enclosed it inside an else .
fixed this
... by record set identifier?
Done

Hi Varsha, some changes I made earlier to provide `LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL` can be applied here as well. Beyond that, on further inspection I think we can improve some of the implementation. Finally, there are some assert()s that are not correct and must be fixed before we can merge this.
Why is this a pointer if it's an in-parameter?

this should be out parameter, corrected it. we read the record handle of the PDR from which entity is removed so we can update the lists carrying PDR info in PLDM that this particular handle has been modified with one entity removed. We need to define this as a pointer because we initialize it in PLDM, call this libpldm API and use that record handle variable.
Added a note in the commit explaining this
I introduced the `LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL` attribute macro in an earlier change. We should use it for this function.
Done
`LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL` here also
Done
`LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL`
Done
`LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL`.
In this case prev can be NULL if record = repo->first. So I cannot add the LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL. Please correct me of I am wrong
Please rebase it on the latest in the main branch, I've added `LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL_ARGS(...)` that allows you to be more specific.
Done
Can you put a blank line above so people don't confuse this as another arm of the original `if (...)` on line 1971?
Done
There's no need to declare `match` at this scope. Move it into the while loop.
Done
There's no need to declare `skip_data_size` at this scope. Move it into the while loop.
Done
There's no need to declare `hdr_type` at this scope. Move it into the while loop.
Done

Why are we calling this `dst`? That's super confusing when there's no `src` to move data from. Can we call this `buf`?

Also there's no need to declare it at this scope. Move it into the while loop.
Done

You mustn't use asserts here, this is a public API, not an internal one. You need to return an error to the caller if these are `NULL` (similarly, you can't use `LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL` either, that's only for internal APIs).
Done
Done
thank you , will keep this in mind
Hi Varsha, only a few minor comments on this one.
which endianness is `record->record_handle`? Host-endianness I hope?
yes, it is host endianness.
Done
Hi Varsha, I think we're getting closer. I have a few comments inline.
This is not part of the v0.9.0 release, can you please move this up to the `## [Unreleased]` section?
Done
It's just called `record_handle` below.
Done
`size_t` please.
Done
Can we please put all the variable definitions before any logic (i.e. move these to the top of the while loop)
Done
Didn't we have a patch allowing this to be `NULL`?

I thought it was not required with the latest LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL change but I can modify it with LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL_ARGS . So I retored that commit , im sorry about the confusion u may need to +1 that commit again- https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/73500

I have added those changes back
Please define this at the top of the loop.
Done
did not use else if for the second as that is the same as above
This formatting isn't very nice. Can you extract this out to its own statement? Same for the remaining instances below.
Done
Hi Varsha, another couple of minor issues, but otherwise I think this is ready to go.
Done

I realise this is contrary to the advice generally applied for C++, but for C projects can you please not default-initialise variables if the value has no meaning? Default-assignment prevents detection of incorrect use of the variable via e.g. valgrind or ubsan.
Done. I have removed the initial value for match variable but clang-tidy is not happy if I remove the initial value of other variables like hdr_type, rc
